awd_titl_txt: Modulation of C. elegans Locomotor Behavior
awd_abstract_narration: Across the animal kingdom, males and females exhibit differences in behavior. Recently, it has become clear that the chromosomal sex of the brain itself (XX or XY) is an important factor in modulating its development and function. Yet very little is known about the process by which genes "tune" the properties of neural circuits to influence behavior. This project focuses on sex differences in the function of the nervous system of a simple invertebrate, the nematode roundworm C. elegans. These tiny worms (each is about the size of a speck of dust) come in two sexes, hermaphrodites (which in C. elegans are slightly modified females) and males. In both sexes, the structure of the nervous system is simple and very well characterized: hermaphrodites have exactly 302 neurons, while males have 383. Of these, both sexes share a so-called "core" set of 294 neurons that control behaviors exhibited by both sexes, including locomotion (movement). Though both sexes move with a characteristic wave-shaped crawl along a moist surface, our laboratory has found that males and hermaphrodites do so differently: males move more quickly and the bends of their bodies are sharper than those of hermaphrodites. This project will use a genetic approach to understand exactly how the function of locomotor circuitry differs between the sex. This project will identify the specific components of this circuitry that are modulated by sex, and to discover how sex chromosomes bring about differences in these components. These results will contribute to a better understanding of the ways in which genes and environment can act in the nervous system to influence its function. In addition, this project will provide intensive research training in advanced neuroscience and genetics for three graduate students and four undergraduates at the University of Rochester.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding how natural variation in behavior is regulated by neural circuits is a fundamental goal of neuroscience and evolutionary biology. One example of this variation is that found between the sexes: in almost all animal species, males and females exhibit different “styles” of shared behaviors. However, it remains unknown how much of these differences come from change in the size and shape (morphology) of the body, and how much comes from regulation of the nervous system itself. The very simple anatomy of the tiny soil worm C. elegans provides an ideal system in which to study these questions. In this species, animals move by propelling waves along the length of their body. However, we have found that movement patterns differ significantly by sex, even though the same neural circuits and muscles control this movement in males and hermaphrodites (the modified females of this species). Using a combination of mathematical modeling, genetic manipulation and behavioral studies, our research has found that both body properties and sex-specific modulation of neuron physiology contribute to these differences. This work, published in the Journal of Neuroscience, highlights the idea that specific “tuning” of the properties of specific neuron types can give rise to important changes in behavior. This provides a framework for understanding how genes regulate behavior, and how changes in gene activity can guide these changes over the life of an organism and the evolution of a species.

 

This research has also made important broader contributions to scientific progress. One graduate student, one postdoctoral fellow and several undergraduate students received extensive, in-depth training in modern neurogenetics. These researchers also had the opportunity to travel to local, national and international scientific meetings, where they presented their work and interacted with experts in the field. Our laboratory also hosted visits from multiple groups of local elementary and high-school students, including groups of students from backgrounds that are traditionally underrepresented in scientific research. These visits and discussions provided them with opportunities to observe scientific research and to hear from student researchers about their training and career paths, informing younger students about opportunities in science that they might not otherwise have considered.
